content:
Diagnosis:
Carcinosarcoma of endometrium, stage T2N1M0, diagnosed March 2024
TP53 mutation positive, p53 abnormal on immunohistochemistry

Previous Treatment:
Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy 15 March 2024
Commenced carboplatin/paclitaxel 12 April 2024

Current Status:
Disease progression on imaging after 2 cycles of chemotherapy

Current Symptoms:
Increasing pelvic pain
New onset right leg swelling
ECOG performance status deteriorated to 2

Investigation Results:
CT pelvis 15 May 2024 shows new 4.2cm pelvic mass with right external iliac lymphadenopathy causing venous compression

Current Plan:
Discussed at Gynae-oncology MDT 16 May 2024
Recommendation to switch to second-line treatment with Doxorubicin

I reviewed [redacted name] today to discuss disease progression and treatment changes. She was accompanied by her daughter. The CT scan unfortunately shows clear evidence of disease progression despite initial chemotherapy, with a new pelvic mass and lymphadenopathy causing venous compression. This explains her increasing pelvic pain and right leg swelling. Her performance status has deteriorated, though she remains suitable for second-line treatment.

I have had a detailed discussion about switching to single-agent Doxorubicin. We discussed the aims of treatment, potential side effects including cardiac toxicity, and the importance of managing her symptoms. She understands this represents a significant change in her disease trajectory but wishes to proceed with further treatment.

Plan:
Commence Doxorubicin 60mg/m2 three-weekly
Urgent referral to lymphoedema service
Baseline echocardiogram arranged
Review in 3 weeks with blood tests
Palliative care team referral for enhanced symptom support

primary_cancer.biomarker_status: TP53 mutation positive, p53 abnormal on immunohistochemistry

cancer_timeline.value: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
CT pelvis shows new 4.2cm pelvic mass with right external iliac lymphadenopathy causing venous compression
Disease progression confirmed on imaging after 2 cycles of chemotherapy
Decision to discontinue carboplatin/paclitaxel due to disease progression

patient_facts.value: CT pelvis 15 May 2024 shows new 4.2cm pelvic mass with right external iliac lymphadenopathy

status_updates.value: Endometrial carcinosarcoma showing disease progression after 2 cycles of first-line chemotherapy. New pelvic mass and lymphadenopathy causing symptomatic deterioration.
Disease progression on CT with new pelvic mass and lymphadenopathy
Plan to switch to second-line treatment with single-agent Doxorubicin 60mg/m2 three-weekly
Review in 3 weeks with blood tests, urgent referral to lymphoedema service, palliative care team referral for enhanced symptom support
